title: Measuring the Ocean
caption: The Ocean Observatories Initiative (OOI) has hundreds of instruments collecting data every minute of every day from locations (arrays) throughout the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans. Here we are looking at data from the Coastal Pioneer (blue box) and and the Global Irminger Sea (red box).

title: The ocean off of the Atlantic Northeast
caption: The Coastal Pioneer location is in the ocean off of Rhode Island and Massachusetts. There are many instruments at this location. Data in this activity were collected from the Central Inshore Profiler Mooring (C at 127m, red) and Central Offshore Profiler Mooring (F at 453m, purple).

title: The ocean off of Greenland
caption: The Global Irminger Sea location is in the ocean off of southern Greenland. There are many instruments at this location. Data in this activity were collected from the Apex Profiler Mooring (B, red box).

title: What does it looks like underwater?
caption: The Wire-Following Profiler (purple box) moves along the cable from 15-70m (Pioneer) or from 240-2,592m (Irminger) below the water surface. It is where these data were collected. Many instruments, each collecting different oceanographic variable data, are included in the Profiler. Data for this activity are from the CTD instruments.

title: How does a CTD work?
caption: The CTD measures and records conductivity, temperature, and pressure as water flows through the instrument, so scientists can calculate the salinity, density, and depth of the water. These CTDs are designed to move up and down while it stores (recovered) and communicates data in real time (telemetered). Pioneer has a Sea-Bird - SBE 52MP and Irminger has a Sea-Bird - SBE 37IM.
